original_table_html:
Gillette Razor Brand History
1971 Trac II: First twin-blade razor
1973 Good News: Top-selling disposable twin-blade razor since introduction
1977 Atra: First twin-blade razor with a pivoting head
1984 Atra Plus: Twin-blade razor with a lubricant strip
1988 Sensor: Individually mounted twin blades
1991 Sensor for Women: First razor designed specifically for women
1993 Sensor Excel: Fitted with microfins that stretch skin for closer shave
1997 Mach3: First triple-blade razor
1999 Mach3 Turbo: Ten microfins as opposed to the five on the original, a new grip and improved lubrication and "anti-friction" blades
2002 M3 Power: First disposable razor to include battery-powered vibration
2006 Fusion: First five-blade razor (included a single sixth blade on the top side of the cartridge)
2009 Fusion ProGlide: Featured re-engineered blades with thinner edges and finished with low-resistance coating
summary_markdown: The Gillette Razor Brand History table outlines a chronological progression of product innovations from 1971 to 2009. The history begins with the introduction of the Trac II, the first twin-blade razor, followed by the disposable Good News razor in 1973. Subsequent developments focused on enhancing the twin-blade design, introducing features like a pivoting head with the Atra (1977), a lubricant strip with Atra Plus (1984), and individually mounted blades with Sensor (1988). The timeline then shows a specific adaptation for women with Sensor for Women (1991) and further refinement with microfins in Sensor Excel (1993). A significant shift occurred in 1997 with the Mach3, the first triple-blade razor, which was later enhanced in 1999 as Mach3 Turbo. The introduction of battery-powered vibration marked the M3 Power in 2002. The evolution continued with the development of a five-blade razor, the Fusion (2006), and culminated in the Fusion ProGlide (2009) with re-engineered, low-resistance blades.
